intro: Sarcomphalus saeri, commonly known as the Sierra carnation, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of California and Nevada. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, characterized by its showy, pink or white flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to dry, sunny environments. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. Sarcomphalus saeri is often found in open habitats such as meadows and slopes, where it contributes to local biodiversity.
